awd_titl_txt: SHINE:  Characterizing the Coronal Origins of Slow Solar Wind using Heavy Ion Composition and Spectroscopic Observations
awd_abstract_narration:
As the most dominant component of the solar wind that engulfs the Earth on the ecliptic plane at 1 AU, the Slow-speed Solar Wind (SSW) plays a substantial role in shaping and determining the Geospace environment and the Earth's upper atmosphere where most of the man-made satellites are located.  However, despite all the efforts devoted to investigating the SSW, two fundamental questions about this type of wind remain unanswered: (1) where does the SSW originate in the corona; and, (2) how do the coronal plasma properties determine the in-situ heavy ion composition of the SSW?  This 3-year SHINE project is aimed at characterizing the coronal origins of the SSW in order to answer these two important science questions.  The project team will study the SSW, utilizing two completely different techniques: in-situ measurements of local wind plasma properties, and remote-sensing spectral or imaging observations. When combined together, these two techniques can become a formidable tool that allows the investigators to fully exploit their potential to study the origin of the SSW.  This project will benefit the solar research community and serve important educational functions.  By using two completely different measurement techniques, this project will serve as a bridge between two different solar physics communities that have been working in parallel with limited interaction: the in-situ community and the remote sensing community, and will thus stimulate a new wave of cross collaborations.  The research will be carried out at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor, where it will support undergraduate education through the University's UROP program and graduate education through collaboration with the graduate students in our department.  The project will also support a young female postdoc, thus helping her establish a career as a woman in STEM disciplines.  The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

This 3-year SHINE project is aimed at characterizing the origin of the solar wind.  In order to achieve this goal, the project team will utilize in-situ measurements from ACE/SWICS and SWEPAM, Ulysses/SWICS, SWOOPS and Wind/SWE and combine the analysis with remote-sensing data from SOHO/MDI, SDO/HMI and Hinode/SOT.  The in-situ solar wind observations will be classified based on their coronal origin types rather then their in-situ properties.  Back-tracking methods will be used to identify the corresponding source regions on the Sun.  The physical properties of the solar wind source regions will be determined using spectral line intensities.  This research project is directly relevant to the NSF's SHINE program, because it will provide important knowledge about the origin of the solar wind.  Such knowledge is critical for accurate modeling and prediction of the space weather conditions from the solar surface to the Earth and beyond.

por.por_cntn:
The proposed investigation was focused on the most important questions concerning the origin of the slow solar wind. In particular, two key questions were answered by the result of this project: 1) Where does the slow solar wind originate? And 2) How does the corona determine the heavy ion composition of the slow solar wind. We found that the amount of different types of solar winds originated from different coronal regions vary dramatically with the solar cycle. For example, the Active-Region-associated wind (AR wind) and the Quiet-Sun wind (QS wind) are majority of the wind during the whole time interval (1998 –2011). While during solar maximum, the AR wind is the majority; and the QS wind is dominated during the solar minimum interval.

The properties of the solar wind originated from different coronal regions are very different. 1) The hotter the coronal origin, the more the elemental abundance ratio, such as Fe/O, was detected; and the higher the charge state ratio, such as O7+/O6+ was measured. The decreasing trends of the O7+/O6+ ratio and the Fe/O ratio are consistent with the order of the wind types from hot coronal regions (active region (AR) and its boundary) to cold regions (Coronal Hole (CH) region and its boundary), which supports the robustness of our solar wind identification method. 2) The influences of the strength of the solar cycle on the hot part of the corona and their associated winds, such as helmet-streamer wind, AR wind, and AR-boundary wind are stronger than on the cold part of corona and their associated winds (QS, CH, and CH-boundary wind). 3) The O7+ O6+ ratio is the most meaningful in-situ signature of all of the measured parameters for differentiating the solar wind types according to their different coronal origins. The six types of the solar wind (AR, AR-boundary, QS, CH, CH-boundary, and helmet-streamer associated wind) can be nicely aligned according to the monotonically decreasing order of the O7+/O6+ ratio. 4) Solar wind proton speed cannot be used as a reliable signature to differentiate the solar wind into different coronal source regions because a great amount of slow speed solar wind originates from the CHs and their boundaries. 5) The majority of the fast speed wind originates from CH and CH boundary regions; however, the origins of slow solar wind can be anywhere, including Helmet-streamer, AR, AR boundary, QS, CH or CH boundary. 

In addition, we found that the depletion of the C6+/C5+ ratio found in the anomalous solar wind and in the Interplanetary Coronal Ejections (CMEs) were due to the large decrease in the abundance of the fully stripped Carbon ion, C6+ (depleted by >80%), but all other non-fully-stripped charge states (e.g., C5+, O7+, and N6+) match normal abundances found in the slow wind and ICMEs. We considered the three main properties of these anomalous solar winds (Outliers) and proposed that magnetic reconnection is the likely origination process for these outlier events, because:

1)  The fact that the Outliers are a minority of the slow winds and ICMEs implies that their origination process needs to be episodic and/or of short duration, such as magnetic reconnection.

2)  The lack of fully stripped ions and the similarity of the rest of the ions in the Outliers compared to the normal solar wind and ICMEs indicate that the process depleting the fully stripped ions must be active in a region of the solar atmosphere where these elements are already (or nearly) frozen-in. Otherwise, the plasma would have time to react to the disappearance of the fully stripped ions and replenish them. Magnetic reconnection occurring at a high height (above the freeze-in height) could cause this effect, and would require that the loop that reconnects with open magnetic flux is large.

3)  The contents of the Outliers, slow solar wind, and ICMEs, as well as their solar cycle dependence, imply that they may originate from active and hot coronal regions, e.g., active regions or their periphery, where the magnetic loops tend to be large. This point agrees with the expectation that the reconnection must occur above the freeze-in height.

These results provids valuable scientific preparation for the analysis of the observations from Heavy Ion Sensor (HIS) onboard Solar Orbiter, allows discrimination between competing slow solar wind heating and acceleration theories, and advances our understanding of the slow wind origin.

The research was carried out at the University of Michigan, where it supports undergraduate education through the University’s UROP program and graduate education through collaboration with the graduate students in our department and group. Multiple undergraduate and graduate students got involved in the project by attending the presentations, discussions, and weekly group meetings.
